questions.text: A medical student is studying the anatomy of the ear and learns about the layers of the tympanic membrane (TM). Which of the following correctly lists the layers of the TM from outermost to innermost?

options.label: A
options.text: Squamous epithelium, Fibrous layer, Mucous membrane

options.label: B
options.text: Mucous membrane, Fibrous layer, Squamous epithelium

options.label: C
options.text: Fibrous layer, Mucous membrane, Squamous epithelium

options.label: D
options.text: Squamous epithelium, Mucous membrane, Fibrous layer

questions.correct_answer: A. Squamous epithelium, Fibrous layer, Mucous membrane
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Squamous Epithelium, Fibrous layer, Mucous membrane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The anatomical layering of the tympanic membrane consists of an outer stratified squamous epithelial layer , a middle fibrous layer , and an inner mucous membrane layer . This knowledge is important for understanding various ear pathologies and their treatments .
  • ➤ anatomical layering
  • ➤ tympanic membrane
  • ➤ outer stratified squamous epithelial layer
  • ➤ middle fibrous layer
  • ➤ an inner mucous membrane layer
  • ➤ ear pathologies
  • ➤ their treatments
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg3
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg3

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with pain localized to his left ear. There is no history of trauma or infection. An ENT specialist notes that the pain could be due to neuralgia involving a specific nerve plexus within the middle ear. Which nerve plexus is most likely involved in mediating this patient's ear pain?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . The carotid plexus is a network of sympathetic nerves surrounding the carotid artery and is not primarily involved in sensory innervation of the ear.
  • • Option B
  • • network of sympathetic nerves
  • • carotid artery
  • • Option C . The cervical plexus provides sensory and motor innervation to structures in the neck , but it does not directly innervate the middle ear or tympanic membrane to a significant extent.
  • • Option C
  • • sensory
  • • motor innervation
  • • structures
  • • neck
  • • Option D . The pharyngeal plexus is primarily involved in innervating the pharynx and does not play a major role in sensory innervation of the ear.
  • • Option D
  • • innervating the pharynx

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The tympanic plexus , primarily formed by the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve , provides sensory innervation to the middle ear and can be involved in ear pain syndromes such as neuralgia .
  • ➤ tympanic plexus
  • ➤ tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve
  • ➤ sensory innervation
  • ➤ middle ear
  • ➤ ear pain syndromes
  • ➤ neuralgia
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg8
  • ➤ Ref:- P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg8

questions.text: A patient develops sweating and flushing over the cheek while eating, following parotid gland surgery. Frey’s syndrome is suspected. Which of the following nerves is involved in the aberrant reinnervation responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Auriculotemporal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Frey’s syndrome results from aberrant regeneration of auriculotemporal nerve fibres that originally carried secretomotor supply to the parotid gland.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the principle and interpretation of the Stenger test in a patient suspected of feigning unilateral hearing loss?

options.label: A
options.text: A patient with true unilateral deafness hears sound only in the affected ear when both ears are stimulated

options.label: B
options.text: A malingerer will deny hearing any sound when the stimulus is stronger in the "deaf" ear and weaker in the normal ear

options.label: C
options.text: The test is used to confirm bilateral conductive hearing loss using tuning forks of different frequencies

options.label: D
options.text: A positive Stenger test confirms the diagnosis of sensorineural hearing loss in both ears

questions.correct_answer: B. A malingerer will deny hearing any sound when the stimulus is stronger in the "deaf" ear and weaker in the normal ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) A malingerer will deny hearing any sound when the stimulus is stronger in the "deaf" ear and weaker in the normal ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Stenger test is used to detect unilateral malingering; if a patient denies hearing when a louder tone is presented to the "deaf" ear, it indicates feigned hearing loss (positive Stenger test).
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 22
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 22

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset vertigo, nausea, and hearing loss in his right ear following a deep scuba diving session earlier in the day. He denies any recent upper respiratory infections, otalgia, or discharge from the ear. On examination, you note horizontal nystagmus and a negative Rinne test on the affected side. The tympanic membrane is intact without signs of inflammation or effusion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Perilymph fistula

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Meniere's disease typically presents with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in the ear . These episodes can last from 20 minutes to several hours , not typically associated with diving or immediate onset after a pressure change.
  • • Option A. Meniere's disease
  • • episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in the ear
  • • 20 minutes to several hours
  • • Option B. Acoustic neuroma is a benign tumor of the cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear nerve) that usually presents with progressive unilateral hearing loss , tinnitus , and sometimes balance disturbances. Its onset is gradual, not sudden after an event like diving.
  • • Option B. Acoustic neuroma
  • • benign tumor
  • • cranial nerve VIII
  • • progressive unilateral hearing loss
  • • tinnitus
  • • balance disturbances.
  • • Option D. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to head position changes . It is caused by dislodged otoliths moving into one of the semicircular canals , leading to inappropriate stimulation of the vestibular system . There's typically no hearing loss associated with BPPV.
  • • Option D. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV)
  • • brief episodes of vertigo
  • • head position changes
  • • dislodged otoliths
  • • semicircular canals
  • • inappropriate stimulation of the vestibular system

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perilymph fistula is a cause of sudden onset vertigo and hearing loss following a pressure-altering event , distinguished by the absence of tympanic membrane inflammation or effusion , and negative findings for other causes of vertigo and hearing loss .
  • ➤ Perilymph fistula
  • ➤ sudden onset vertigo
  • ➤ hearing loss
  • ➤ pressure-altering event
  • ➤ absence of tympanic membrane inflammation or effusion
  • ➤ negative findings
  • ➤ vertigo and hearing loss

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of vertigo, particularly when she turns her head quickly. To assess her vestibular function, the physician decides to perform a Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test. Which of the following outcomes of this test is considered normal?

options.label: A
options.text: Absence of nystagmus with both warm and cold water irrigation

options.label: B
options.text: Direction-changing nystagmus with warm water irrigation in the left ear and cold water irrigation in the right ear

options.label: C
options.text: Nystagmus beating toward the irrigated ear with warm water and away from the irrigated ear with cold water

options.label: D
options.text: Stronger nystagmus with cold water irrigation than with warm water irrigation in both ears

questions.correct_answer: C. Nystagmus beating toward the irrigated ear with warm water and away from the irrigated ear with cold water
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nystagmus beating toward the irrigated ear with warm water and away from the irrigated ear with cold water

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Absence of nystagmus with both warm and cold water irrigation: This outcome is abnormal . The normal response to caloric testing involves the induction of nystagmus , which is a rapid, involuntary movement of the eyes . The absence of nystagmus may indicate a vestibular dysfunction.
  • • Option A. Absence of nystagmus with both warm and cold water irrigation:
  • • abnormal
  • • normal response to caloric testing
  • • induction of nystagmus
  • • rapid, involuntary movement of the eyes
  • • Option B. Direction-changing nystagmus with warm water irrigation in the left ear and cold water irrigation in the right ear: While nystagmus direction can change based on the ear being irrigated and the temperature of the water , this option does not accurately describe the expected directional pattern for a normal response.
  • • Option B. Direction-changing nystagmus with warm water irrigation in the left ear and cold water irrigation in the right ear:
  • • nystagmus direction
  • • ear being irrigated and the temperature of the water
  • • Option D. Stronger nystagmus with cold water irrigation than with warm water irrigation in both ears: The strength of nystagmus is not the primary indicator of a normal response in the caloric test . The direction of the nystagmus in relation to the ear being irrigated and the temperature of the water is more relevant.
  • • Option D. Stronger nystagmus with cold water irrigation than with warm water irrigation in both ears:
  • • strength of nystagmus
  • • not the primary indicator of a normal response
  • • caloric test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test evaluates vestibular function by inducing nystagmus through the irrigation of the external auditory canal with warm and cold water . The normal response is nystagmus that beats toward the irrigated ear with warm water and away with cold water.
  • ➤ Fitzgerald-Hallpike bithermal caloric test
  • ➤ vestibular function by inducing nystagmus through the irrigation of the external auditory canal
  • ➤ warm and cold water

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It is the shortest and narrowest segment, making it vulnerable to compression-related paralysis

Ans. C) It is the shortest and narrowest segment, making it vulnerable to compression-related paralysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The labyrinthine segment of the facial nerve is the shortest and narrowest portion, making it highly susceptible to compression-induced facial paralysis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, a professional singer, presents with complaints of a progressive swelling in the neck and a change in voice quality over the past few months. He denies any respiratory distress. On examination, a soft, compressible mass is palpated in the neck that increases in size with Valsalva maneuver. Laryngoscopy reveals an air-filled dilation of the laryngeal saccule. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Laryngocele

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Thyroglossal duct cyst are developmental cysts that usually present in the midline of the neck. They move with swallowing or protrusion of the tongue. However, they are not air-filled and do not increase in size with the Valsalva maneuver.
  • • Option A
  • • developmental cysts
  • • midline
  • • swallowing
  • • protrusion
  • • Option B . Branchial cleft cyst are congenital epithelial cysts arising on the lateral part of the neck from the remnants of the branchial apparatus . They do not typically change in size with maneuvers like Valsalva.
  • • Option B
  • • congenital epithelial cysts
  • • lateral part
  • • remnants
  • • branchial apparatus
  • • Option D . Cystic hygroma is a congenital lymphatic malformation typically presenting in infancy or early childhood . It's a fluid-filled lesion , not air-filled, and doesn't change size with Valsalva maneuver.
  • • Option D
  • • congenital lymphatic malformation
  • • infancy
  • • early childhood
  • • fluid-filled lesion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngocele is an air-filled dilation of the laryngeal saccule that can increase in size with increased intrathoracic pressure , such as during the Valsalva maneuver, often seen in individuals who frequently increase their intrathoracic pressure.
  • ➤ air-filled dilation
  • ➤ laryngeal saccule
  • ➤ increase
  • ➤ size
  • ➤ increased intrathoracic pressure
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 305
  • ➤ Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 305

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe respiratory distress and audible stridor. She has a history of recent extensive neck surgery. Laryngoscopic examination reveals both vocal cords in the median position. What is the most likely cause of her acute respiratory distress?

options.label: B
options.text: Bilateral vocal cord paralysis due to recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy

questions.correct_answer: B. Bilateral vocal cord paralysis due to recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bilateral vocal cord paralysis due to recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute allergic laryngeal edema: Incorrect . While acute allergic reactions can cause laryngeal edema and stridor , the laryngoscopic finding of both vocal cords in the median position is more indicative of a neurogenic cause rather than an allergic one .
  • • Option A. Acute allergic laryngeal edema:
  • • Incorrect
  • • cause laryngeal edema
  • • stridor
  • • laryngoscopic finding of both vocal cords
  • • median position
  • • neurogenic cause rather than an allergic one
  • • Option C. Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve (SLN. palsy: Incorrect . Isolated SLN palsy would affect the cricothyroid muscle , changing the voice pitch and tension of the vocal cords , but it would not result in median positioning of the vocal cords leading to airway obstruction.
  • • Option C. Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve (SLN. palsy:
  • • Incorrect
  • • Isolated SLN palsy
  • • affect the cricothyroid muscle
  • • changing the voice pitch
  • • tension of the vocal cords
  • • Option D. Acute laryngeal trauma: Incorrect . Acute trauma could cause stridor due to swelling or hematoma but would not necessarily place both vocal cords in the median position without associated neurogenic paralysis.
  • • Option D. Acute laryngeal trauma:
  • • Incorrect
  • • stridor due to swelling or hematoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilateral RLN palsy can result in both vocal cords lying in the median position due to unopposed action of the cricothyroid muscles , leading to airway obstruction and presenting with stridor , which can be life-threatening and may require emergency tracheostomy to restore the airway.
  • ➤ Bilateral RLN palsy
  • ➤ both vocal cords lying in the median position
  • ➤ unopposed action of the cricothyroid muscles
  • ➤ airway obstruction
  • ➤ presenting with stridor

questions.text: A 30-year-old music teacher presents with a complaint of progressive hoarseness over the last six months. She denies any respiratory infections, smoking, or other medical issues but mentions that her job requires extensive vocal use. On laryngoscopy, small bilateral lesions are observed at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cords. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vocal Nodules

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Laryngeal papillomatosis is caused by HPV , leads to the development of multiple wart-like growths on the larynx . It is less likely given the patient's symptoms and the characteristic appearance of the lesions on laryngoscopy.
  • • Option A
  • • HPV
  • • development
  • • multiple wart-like growths
  • • larynx
  • • Option B. Vocal cord polyps are usually unilateral, peducnculated and may be associated with vocal abuse , but they tend to be larger and more vascular than nodules. The bilateral and small nature of the lesions in this patient is more indicative of vocal nodules. Site is junction of Anterior 1/3rd & Posterior 2/3rd of vocal cords.
  • • Option B.
  • • unilateral, peducnculated
  • • vocal abuse
  • • tend
  • • larger
  • • more vascular
  • • Option D. Reinke's edema is characterized by swelling of the vocal cords , usually related to smoking or other irritants. It does not present with small bilateral lesions at the junction of the vocal cords as described in this case.
  • • Option D.
  • • swelling
  • • vocal cords
  • • smoking

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnose vocal nodules in patients presenting with progressive hoarseness , especially in those with extensive vocal usage , and recognize their appearance as small bilateral lesions at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two-thirds of the vocal cords on laryngoscopy . Vocal cord Nodules are Bilateral & Sessile. Also known as Screamer`s /Singer`s /Teacher`s nodule due to Prolonged Voice Abuse. Mx is Voice Rest & Speech therapy.
  • ➤ Diagnose vocal nodules
  • ➤ progressive hoarseness
  • ➤ extensive vocal usage
  • ➤ appearance
  • ➤ small bilateral lesions
  • ➤ junction
  • ➤ anterior one-third
  • ➤ posterior two-thirds
  • ➤ vocal cords
  • ➤ laryngoscopy
  • ➤ Ref : P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 303
  • ➤ Ref : P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6 th Edition, pg 303

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the inferior turbinate is correct?

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with Nasal Trauma sustained during a Soccer Game. On examination, he has a Tender Fluctuant Swelling of the Nasal Septum. There is no evidence of nasal bone fracture or other facial injuries. The most likely diagnosis is a Septal Hematoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate Incision and Drainage in the Emergency Department

questions.correct_answer: B. Immediate Incision and Drainage in the Emergency Department
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Immediate Incision and Drainage in the Emergency Department

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . While antibiotics are important to prevent infection , they are not sufficient as the sole treatment for a septal hematoma . A septal hematoma requires active intervention to prevent complications .

  • • prevent complications
  • • Option C . Nasal decongestants and analgesics may provide symptomatic relief for nasal congestion and pain but do not address the underlying issue of a septal hematoma.
  • • Option C
  • • symptomatic relief
  • • nasal congestion
  • • pain
  • • Option D . While cold compresses can help reduce swelling , observation alone is not an appropriate management strategy for a septal hematoma due to the risk of complications.
  • • Option D
  • • reduce swelling
  • • observation
  • • not
  • • appropriate management strategy
  • • septal hematoma
  • • Septal hematoma –
  • • Collection of blood between cartilage and it’s perichondrium .
  • • Collection
  • • cartilage
  • • perichondrium
  • • Causes – trauma , surgery , bleeding disorders .
  • • trauma
  • • surgery
  • • bleeding disorders
  • • Clinical features – Bilateral obstruction , frontal headache , sense of pressure over nasal bridge .
  • • Bilateral obstruction
  • • frontal headache
  • • sense
  • • pressure
  • • nasal bridge
  • • Examination – smooth rounded swelling of septum in both cavities .
  • • smooth rounded swelling
  • • septum
  • • both cavities
  • • On palpation → soft & fluctuant .
  • • soft
  • • fluctuant
  • • Treatment – Incision & drainage immediately , then packing + antibiotics .
  • • Incision
  • • drainage immediately
  • • packing + antibiotics
  • • Complications –
  • • Complications –
  • • (1) Fibrous Change → permanently thickened septum .
  • • Fibrous Change
  • • permanently thickened septum
  • • (2) Secondary Infection → abscess with cartilage necrosis → Dorsum Depressed ( Saddling ).
  • • Secondary Infection
  • • abscess
  • • cartilage necrosis
  • • Dorsum Depressed
  • • Saddling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The appropriate management of a septal hematoma involves immediate incision and drainage in the emergency department to prevent complications like cartilage necrosis and septal perforation . This knowledge is essential for medical residents, particularly in emergency medicine and otolaryngology, for the effective management of nasal trauma-related complications.

questions.text: Foul smelling discharge with nasal crusting and ‘Merciful anosmia’ is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Atrophic Rhinitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hypertrophied Rhinitis involves the thickening of the nasal mucosa , leading to nasal obstruction . However, it does not typically present with foul-smelling discharge, nasal crusting, or anosmia (loss of smell).
  • • Option A.
  • • thickening
  • • nasal mucosa
  • • nasal obstruction
  • • Option B. Vasomotor rhinitis, characterized by hyperreactivity of the nasal mucosa to various triggers (like changes in temperature , humidity , or exposure to irritants ), vasomotor rhinitis presents with symptoms like nasal congestion and rhinorrhea , but not with the foul-smelling discharge or crusting typical of atrophic rhinitis.
  • • Option B.
  • • hyperreactivity
  • • nasal mucosa
  • • triggers
  • • changes
  • • temperature
  • • humidity
  • • exposure
  • • irritants
  • • vasomotor rhinitis
  • • symptoms
  • • nasal congestion
  • • rhinorrhea
  • • Option D. Allergic Fungal Sinusitis involves an allergic reaction to fungal elements in the sinuses , leading to symptoms like nasal congestion , sinus pressure , and possible decrease in smell . While it can involve nasal discharge and crusting , it is not typically associated with the foul-smelling discharge or 'merciful anosmia' seen in atrophic rhinitis.
  • • Option D.
  • • allergic reaction
  • • fungal elements
  • • sinuses
  • • nasal congestion
  • • sinus pressure
  • • possible decrease
  • • smell
  • • nasal discharge
  • • crusting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrophic rhinitis is the condition characterized by a thick , foul-smelling nasal discharge , nasal crusting , and ' merciful anosmia' .

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with mild dysphagia, posterior throat discomfort, and a gradually enlarging midline swelling on the posterior pharyngeal wall. He also has multiple cervical lymph nodes and a history of weight loss and low-grade fever. Cervical spine X-ray reveals destruction of C3 and C4 vertebral bodies. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: IV antibiotics and emergency incision and drainage

options.label: B

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presented with mild ocular redness for the past 4 months. On examination, he had large keratic precipitates with minimal flare. The likely etiology for this condition includes all except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reiter syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Reiter's syndrome , also known as reactive arthritis , is a type of inflammatory arthritis that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body , often the intestines, genitals, or urinary tract . It is classified as a form of spondyloarthritis , which is a group of joint diseases that specifically affect the spine and the areas where the tendons and ligaments attach to bones.
  • • Reiter's syndrome
  • • reactive arthritis
  • • inflammatory arthritis that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body
  • • intestines, genitals, or urinary tract
  • • form of spondyloarthritis
  • • The key features of Reiter's syndrome include:
  • • Arthritis : Swelling, pain, and stiffness of the joints, especially the knees, ankles, and feet. It can also affect the fingers, wrists, elbows, and spine. Urethritis : Inflammation of the urethra, which can cause pain during urination and an increased urge to urinate. Conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the lining of the eye, leading to redness, irritation, and discomfort. Enthesitis : Inflammation at the sites where tendons or ligaments insert into the bone, particularly at the heels, toes, or spine. Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions : Some people may develop skin rashes, sores in the mouth, or keratoderma blennorrhagica (small, painless, hard nodules on the palms and soles).
  • • Arthritis : Swelling, pain, and stiffness of the joints, especially the knees, ankles, and feet. It can also affect the fingers, wrists, elbows, and spine.
  • • Arthritis : Swelling, pain, and stiffness of the joints, especially the knees, ankles, and feet. It can also affect the fingers, wrists, elbows, and spine.
  • • Arthritis
  • • Urethritis : Inflammation of the urethra, which can cause pain during urination and an increased urge to urinate.
  • • Urethritis : Inflammation of the urethra, which can cause pain during urination and an increased urge to urinate.
  • • Urethritis
  • • Conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the lining of the eye, leading to redness, irritation, and discomfort.
  • • Conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the lining of the eye, leading to redness, irritation, and discomfort.
  • • Conjunctivitis:
  • • Enthesitis : Inflammation at the sites where tendons or ligaments insert into the bone, particularly at the heels, toes, or spine.
  • • Enthesitis : Inflammation at the sites where tendons or ligaments insert into the bone, particularly at the heels, toes, or spine.
  • • Enthesitis
  • • Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions : Some people may develop skin rashes, sores in the mouth, or keratoderma blennorrhagica (small, painless, hard nodules on the palms and soles).
  • • Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions : Some people may develop skin rashes, sores in the mouth, or keratoderma blennorrhagica (small, painless, hard nodules on the palms and soles).
  • • Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions
  • • The exact cause of Reiter's syndrome is not known, but it is believed to be triggered by certain bacterial infections. Commonly implicated bacteria include Chlamydia trachomatis, which is sexually transmitted, and certain gastrointestinal bacteria like Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, and Campylobacter.
  • • triggered by certain bacterial infections.
  • • The treatment of Reiter's syndrome focuses on relieving symptoms and includes the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), corticosteroids, and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). Antibiotics may be used if a bacterial infection is identified as the trigger. Additionally, physical therapy can help maintain joint function and range of motion.
  • • includes the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
  • • corticosteroids, and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs
  • • Most people with Reiter's syndrome recover fully from the initial episode within 12 months, but some may experience chronic arthritis or recurrent episodes of the disease.

Reiter's syndrome, also known as reactive arthritis, is the classic triad of conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis occurring after an infection, particularly those in the urogenital or gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: Which among the following is a method of short-term storage after eye ball retrieval?

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the guidelines laid down by the government of India for organising eye camps?

questions.correct_answer: B. At least 5 operating surgeons should be present
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) At least 5 operating surgeons should be present

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Presently SICS & Phacoemulsification Techniques are Recommended : Small Incision Cataract Surgery (SICS) and Phacoemulsification are modern and efficient techniques for cataract surgery . These methods are indeed recommended for their safety, effectiveness, and relatively quick recovery times.
  • • Option A

  • • Phacoemulsification
  • • modern
  • • efficient techniques for cataract surgery
  • • Option C . Both the Eyes Should Never be Operated at One Go : This is a standard guideline in eye care , especially in camp settings . Operating on both eyes simultaneously increases the risk of complications, including infection. Therefore, it is recommended to operate on one eye at a time.
  • • Option C
  • • Both the Eyes Should Never be Operated at One Go
  • • standard guideline in eye care
  • • camp settings
  • • Option D . Cases with Surgical Risks Such as Diabetes, Hypertensives & Cardiac Problems Should Not be Operated in Camps : This statement is generally true. Patients with systemic conditions like diabetes , hypertension , or cardiac problems are at a higher risk of complications during and after surgery . Such cases typically require more comprehensive pre-operative and post-operative care than what might be available at an eye camp.

questions.text: A patient undergoing perimetry has the following visual field defect. What is the pupillary abnormality expected in this case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Wernicke’s pupil

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Argyll Robertson Pupil: This is a condition where pupils are small and irregular but do not constrict when exposed to bright light (light-near dissociation). They do, however, constrict with accommodation . It is classically associated with neurosyphilis, particularly tabes dorsalis, and does not have a direct correlation with homonymous hemianopia.
  • • Option A
  • • Argyll Robertson Pupil:
  • • condition where pupils are small and irregular but do not constrict
  • • exposed to bright light
  • • constrict with accommodation
  • • Option B. Adie’s Pupil: Also known as tonic pupil , it is usually unilateral and is larger than the other pupil . It reacts poorly to light but may have a better near response. This condition is caused by damage to the postganglionic fibers of the parasympathetic innervation of the eye and is not related to visual field defects.
  • • Option B.
  • • Adie’s Pupil:
  • • tonic pupil
  • • unilateral and is larger than the other pupil
  • • condition is caused by damage to the postganglionic fibers
  • • Option C. Marcus Gunn Pupil: Also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), it is a sign of asymmetrical optic nerve dysfunction . It is detected using the swinging flashlight test . However, in homonymous hemianopia, the optic nerve function is typically preserved until the optic chiasm, so a Marcus Gunn pupil is not expected.
  • • Option C.
  • • Marcus Gunn Pupil:
  • • relative afferent pupillary defect
  • • sign of asymmetrical optic nerve dysfunction
  • • detected using the swinging flashlight test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a case of right homonymous hemianopia , the lesion lies at the level of left optic tract , and the pupillary abnormality seen in these cases will be Wernicke’s pupil .
  • ➤ right homonymous hemianopia
  • ➤ lesion lies at the level of left optic tract
  • ➤ pupillary abnormality
  • ➤ Wernicke’s pupil

questions.text: In Worth four dot test, the patient’s perception is shown in the image below. What would be the interpretation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Orthophoria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Right Suppression : A person with suppression of the right eye will see only two green dots because the right eye (covered by the red lens) suppresses the red dot, and the white dot appears green through the green lens of the left eye.
  • • Option A.
  • • Right Suppression
  • • suppression of the right eye will see only two green dots because the right eye
  • • Option B. Left Suppression : A person with suppression of the left eye will see three dots - two green and one red . The left eye (covered by the green lens) suppresses the green dots, and the white dot appears red through the red lens of the right eye.
  • • Option B.
  • • Left Suppression
  • • left eye will see three dots - two green and one red
  • • Option D. Diplopia : If the person has double vision (diplopia), they will see five dots - three green (two from the right eye and one white dot seen as green by the left eye) and two red (one from the left eye and one white dot seen as red by the right eye).
  • • Option D.
  • • Diplopia
  • • person has double vision
  • • will see five dots

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Worth Four Dot Test results vary based on the patient's visual condition : right suppression shows two green dots , left suppression shows two green and one red dot , orthophoria shows two green , one red , and one combined dot , and diplopia shows three green and two red dots.

  • ➤ based on the patient's visual condition

  • ➤ left suppression shows two green

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of distressing thoughts that are recurrent and intrusive. He states these thoughts often go against his personal values and beliefs, causing him significant distress. He recognizes these thoughts as his own but feels they are not in line with his true self. Which of the following terms best describes the nature of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ego-dystonic

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Ego-syntonic: Thoughts or behaviors that are in harmony with the needs and goals of the self . These are consistent with a person's self-image, and the individual doesn't see them as problematic.
  • • Option B: Ego-syntonic: Thoughts or behaviors that are in harmony with the needs and goals of the self
  • • Option C: Ego-ideal: This is a psychoanalytic term representing an individual's idealized self, the embodiment of all the qualities one aspires to have.
  • • Option C: Ego-ideal:
  • • psychoanalytic term representing an individual's idealized self,
  • • Option D: Ego-neutral: This term is not standardly used in clinical psychology or psychiatry. Ego-neutral would imply that something is neither congruent nor in conflict with the self-image or ego.
  • • Option D: Ego-neutral:
  • • not standardly used in clinical psychology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obsessions , as seen in Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD), are typically ego-dystonic, meaning thoughts or behaviors that are unwanted and unacceptable. On the other hand, certain personality disorders might have traits that are ego-syntonic, where the behaviors or thoughts are not seen as problematic by the individual, even if they are maladaptive.
  • ➤ Obsessions
  • ➤ Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
  • ➤ ego-dystonic, meaning thoughts or behaviors that are unwanted and unacceptable.
  • ➤ Ref: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 5th edition, Page No 46.
  • ➤ Ref: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 5th edition, Page No 46.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to a psychiatrist with a history of excessive happiness, hyper-religiosity, and increased energy for the past 10 days. He reports needing only 4 hours of sleep each night and has been unusually talkative at work. Based on his symptoms, he was diagnosed with a hypomanic episode. Additionally, his medical history reveals three episodes of depression and one episode of mania in the past. What is the diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bipolar Type 1 Disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A single manic/mixed episode is enough to make the diagnosis of Bipolar type I disorder. The patient in the case has a history of one manic episode, which is sufficient for a diagnosis of Bipolar Type I Disorder, regardless of the current hypomanic episode or the past depressive episodes

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is diagnosed with borderline personality disorder after multiple presentations to the psychiatric clinic, each time with intense interpersonal issues, impulsivity, and self-harm tendencies. As part of her comprehensive treatment plan, which therapeutic approach has been shown to be the most effective in managing individuals with this disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT).

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT): While CBT can be useful for certain symptoms and can be a part of the treatment regime , DBT is the primary therapeutic approach specifically designed for BPD.
  • • Option A. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT):
  • • useful for certain symptoms
  • • part of the treatment regime
  • • Option C. Group therapy : Group therapy can be beneficial in treating some aspects of BPD , but it isn't the primary therapeutic modality used for this condition.
  • • Option
  • • C. Group therapy
  • • beneficial in treating some aspects of BPD
  • • Option D. Psychodynamic psychotherapy : While this approach can offer insights into unconscious thought patterns and behaviors , it's not the first-line therapy for BPD.
  • • Option
  • • D. Psychodynamic psychotherapy
  • • offer insights into unconscious thought patterns and behaviors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dialectical behavior therapy is a therapy that has been designed for the treatment of borderline personality disorder . Medications used in BPD include antipsychotics, antidepressants, and mood stabilizers like carbamazepine.
  • ➤ Dialectical behavior therapy
  • ➤ therapy that has been designed for the treatment of borderline personality disorder
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 573.
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 573.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the psychiatric clinic with a history of unstable relationships, impulsive behavior, and intense episodes of anger. She reports a chronic feeling of emptiness and struggles with self-identity. Her psychiatrist considers a personality disorder diagnosis as per ICD-11 criteria. Which of the following best describes the classification of personality disorders in ICD-11?

options.label: B
options.text: Diagnosed based on severity and predominant personality traits

options.label: C
options.text: Based on the presence of psychotic symptoms

options.label: D
options.text: Diagnosed only in individuals above 30 years of age

questions.correct_answer: B. Diagnosed based on severity and predominant personality traits
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Diagnosed based on severity and predominant personality traits

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Categorized into 10 specific types : This describes the classification system used by the DSM-5 , not ICD-11.
  • • Option A. Categorized into 10 specific types
  • • classification system used by the DSM-5
  • • Option C. Based on the presence of psychotic symptoms : Psychotic symptoms are not used to classify personality disorders in ICD-11 . Personality disorders are characterized by enduring patterns of behavior and inner experience that deviate markedly from the expectations of the individual's culture, are pervasive and inflexible, and lead to distress or impairment.
  • • Option C. Based on the presence of psychotic symptoms
  • • Psychotic symptoms
  • • not used to classify personality disorders in ICD-11
  • • Option D. Diagnosed only in individuals above 30 years of age : Personality disorders can be diagnosed in adults of any age , not just those above 30, as long as the maladaptive patterns are stable over time and lead to distress or impairment.
  • • Option D. Diagnosed only in individuals above 30 years of age
  • • Personality disorders
  • • diagnosed in adults of any age

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In ICD-11 , the older classification of personality disorders (e.g. schizoid, paranoid, narcissistic, etc) has been removed . According to ICD-11, personality disorders have been divided according to the severity of symptoms into:
  • ➤ ICD-11
  • ➤ older classification of personality disorders
  • ➤ has been removed
  • ➤ Mild personality disorder Moderate personality disorder Severe personality disorder
  • ➤ Mild personality disorder
  • ➤ Mild personality disorder
  • ➤ Moderate personality disorder
  • ➤ Moderate personality disorder
  • ➤ Severe personality disorder
  • ➤ Severe personality disorder
  • ➤ According to ICD-11 , depending on the specific symptoms present, a specifier of a prominent personality trait' can be added after the diagnosis , e.g. a person who does not follow rules doesn't care for the feelings of others, does not have any guilt feeling will get a diagnosis of moderate personality disorder (dissociality in personality disorder). This patient according to ICD-10 would have received a diagnosis of Dissocial Personality disorder.
  • ➤ According to ICD-11
  • ➤ specifier of a prominent personality trait' can be added after the diagnosis
  • ➤ Ref : International Classification of Diseases, 11th edition, Page No 174-177.
  • ➤ Ref : International Classification of Diseases, 11th edition, Page No 174-177.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with significant weight loss over the past eight months. She reports an intense fear of gaining weight and a persistent dissatisfaction with her body image. Her BMI is 16.2 kg/m². She also admits to engaging in episodes of binge eating followed by purging behaviors, such as self-induced vomiting and excessive exercise. What is the most appropriate diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anorexia nervosa, binge-eating/purging type

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anorexia nervosa, binge-eating type is characterized by significant weight loss, a distorted body image, and episodes of binge eating followed by compensatory behaviors such as self-induced vomiting or misuse of laxatives. In anorexia nervosa, the patient has a significantly low weight (BMI < 18.5 kg/m²), while in bulimia nervosa, weight is typically normal or slightly elevated and the presence of binge-eating and purging behaviors determines the subtype (restrictive vs. binge-eating/purging), but does not change the primary diagnosis.
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 471.
  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: You are consulted regarding a 14-year-old boy who has recently been displaying symptoms of depression. His school teacher reports that he appeared to become sad suddenly over a week, often seeming distant and preoccupied. His mother shares that he has moments where he claims to hear voices telling him he's worthless. On some days, he shifts rapidly between bouts of crying and periods of irritability. During the clinic visit, you observe that he frequently fidgets, can't sit still, and displays signs of restlessness. Given this presentation, which of the following features in this child's depressive episode is least indicative of a future risk of developing bipolar disorder?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Psychomotor agitation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Rapid onset of depression: A sudden or rapid onset of depressive symptoms can be indicative of bipolar disorder , as mood episodes in bipolar disorder often have a more acute onset compared to unipolar depression.
  • • Option A. Rapid onset of depression:
  • • rapid onset of depressive symptoms
  • • indicative of bipolar disorder
  • • Option B. Psychotic symptoms: The presence of psychotic symptoms, such as auditory hallucinations, during a depressive episode can suggest a higher likelihood of bipolar disorder . In pediatric cases, psychotic symptoms in depression warrant a careful assessment for bipolarity.
  • • Option B. Psychotic symptoms:
  • • auditory hallucinations, during a depressive episode can suggest a higher likelihood of bipolar disorder
  • • Option C. Mood lability: Rapid shifts in mood , such as quickly going from sadness to irritability, are suggestive of bipolarity and an increased risk of bipolar disorder.
  • • Option C. Mood lability:
  • • Rapid shifts in mood
  • • going from sadness to irritability,
  • • bipolarity and an increased risk of bipolar disorder.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 385.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 385.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the psychiatric clinic with a history of fluctuating mood patterns. She reports experiencing periods of elevated energy, increased creativity, and decreased need for sleep, but these episodes are not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning. Additionally, she experiences periods of low mood, fatigue, and decreased interest in activities, but these episodes do not meet the full criteria for a major depressive episode. These mood fluctuations have been present for the past 3 years, with no symptom-free period lasting longer than 2 months. Based on her clinical presentation, which of the following statements is correct about her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: There is at least one episode of mania

options.label: B
options.text: The duration criterion for diagnosis is 2 years

options.label: C
options.text: There is at least one episode of depression

options.label: D
options.text: There is at least one episode of hypomania

questions.correct_answer: B. The duration criterion for diagnosis is 2 years
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The duration criterion for diagnosis is 2 years

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: There is at least one episode of mania: Mania is not present in Cyclothymic Disorder . If a manic episode occurs, the diagnosis would change to Bipolar I Disorder.
  • • Option A: There is at least one episode of mania:
  • • not present in Cyclothymic Disorder
  • • Option C: There is at least one episode of depression: The depressive symptoms in Cyclothymic Disorder do not meet the full criteria for a major depressive episode .
  • • Option C: There is at least one episode of depression:
  • • do not meet the full criteria for a major depressive episode
  • • Option D: There is at least one episode of hypomania: In Cyclothymic Disorder, while symptoms resembling hypomania are present , they may not always be sufficiently severe or prolonged to meet the full criteria for a hypomanic episode. Therefore, the presence of a hypomanic episode is not an absolute criterion for diagnosing cyclothymia.
  • • Option D: There is at least one episode of hypomania:
  • • hypomania are present
  • • hypomanic episode is not an absolute criterion for diagnosing cyclothymia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cyclothymia is a milder form of bipolar disorder , in which manic symptoms and depressive symptoms occur , but they are never severe enough to make a diagnosis of mania or depression. The symptoms should last for at least 2 years .
  • ➤ Cyclothymia
  • ➤ milder form of bipolar disorder
  • ➤ manic symptoms and depressive symptoms occur
  • ➤ symptoms should last for at least 2 years
  • ➤ Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 369.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 369.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, previously diagnosed with bipolar disorder, is admitted due to an acute manic phase. She exhibits elation, rapid speech with frequent topic shifts, and claims she's the "next Virgin Mary" chosen by God. Initial blood tests including BUN, creatinine, electrolytes, and TSH, as well as an ECG, are all normal. After conducting the necessary evaluations, the decision is made to initiate her on lithium therapy. How long, with consistent dosing, will it take for the medication to reach a steady state in her system?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Less than 24 hours is too short for lithium to reach a steady state.
  • • Option A.
  • • Less than 24 hours
  • • too short for lithium
  • • Option B. 4 days is close , but slightly less than the standard time for lithium to reach its steady state.
  • • Option B.
  • • 4 days is close
  • • less than the standard time
  • • Option D. 2 to 3 weeks is a longer duration than required for lithium to reach a steady state.
  • • Option D.
  • • 2 to 3 weeks is a longer duration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Half-life of Lithium is 24 hours. Lithium reaches a steady state in the body after approximately 5 days (or 5 half-lives) with regular administration. Hence serum lithium levels are obtained 5 days after initiation or dose adjustment of lithium. Lithium is excreted in urine (99%).
  • ➤ Half-life of Lithium is 24 hours.
  • ➤ Lithium reaches a steady state
  • ➤ after approximately 5 days
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 649 .

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with a history of bipolar disorder is seen in the outpatient psychiatric clinic for a medication review. She has been stabilized on carbamazepine for the past year. Now, she inquires about the potential side effects of her medication. Which of the following side effects that she mentions is a dose-dependent adverse effect of carbamazepine, rather than an idiosyncratic one?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Double vision.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Agranulocytosis: This is a rare but serious reduction in white blood cells that can occur with carbamazepine use . It is not dose-dependent and requires immediate medical attention if suspected.
  • • Option A. Agranulocytosis:
  • • rare but serious reduction in white blood cells
  • • carbamazepine use
  • • not dose-dependent
  • • Option C. Stevens-Johnson syndrome: This is a severe and potentially life-threatening skin reaction . This is an idiosyncratic reaction associated with carbamazepine, especially in individuals with the HLA-B*1502 allele.
  • • Option C. Stevens-Johnson syndrome:
  • • severe and potentially life-threatening skin reaction
  • • Option D. Pancreatitis: Although a rare side effect , pancreatitis associated with carbamazepine is considered idiosyncratic and not dose-dependent.
  • • Option D. Pancreatitis:
  • • rare side effect
  • • pancreatitis
  • • carbamazepine
  • • idiosyncratic and not dose-dependent.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with a history of severe depression is admitted to the psychiatric unit for treatment. He has been started on Amitriptyline and, after 4 weeks of therapy, shows significant improvement in his depressive symptoms. He no longer reports feelings of hopelessness and has started to engage more with his family and hospital staff. As his physician, you are preparing for his discharge and considering the potential risks associated with his medication at this stage of treatment. At the time of his discharge, which of the following is the most important concern with Amitriptyline therapy in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Suicidal tendencies with overdose of Amitriptyline

options.label: D
options.text: Prescribing modafinil to counteract sedation due to Amitriptyline

questions.correct_answer: A. Suicidal tendencies with overdose of Amitriptyline
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Suicidal tendencies with overdose of Amitriptyline

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Therapeutic drug monitoring of Amitriptyline: While important in the long-term management to ensure therapeutic levels and prevent toxicity , it is not typically the most critical concern at discharge.
  • • Option B. Therapeutic drug monitoring of Amitriptyline:
  • • long-term management to ensure therapeutic levels
  • • prevent toxicity
  • • Option C. ECG monitoring for arrhythmias: Amitriptyline can cause cardiac arrhythmias, particularly in overdose or in patients with pre-existing heart conditions . Regular ECG monitoring is advisable but secondary to the concern of suicidal tendencies in the immediate discharge period.
  • • Option C. ECG monitoring for arrhythmias: Amitriptyline
  • • cardiac arrhythmias,
  • • overdose or in patients with pre-existing heart conditions
  • • Option D. Prescribing modafinil to counteract sedation due to Amitriptyline: While Amitriptyline can cause sedation, addressing the risk of suicidal ideation and overdose is a more pressing concern. Modafinil is not commonly prescribed solely to counteract sedation from antidepressants and has its own set of considerations and potential side effects.
  • • Option D. Prescribing modafinil to counteract sedation due to Amitriptyline:
  • • Amitriptyline can cause sedation,
  • • addressing the risk of suicidal ideation
  • • overdose is a more pressing concern.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In certain cases, a person with depression might die by suicide while their symptoms show signs of improvement after beginning antidepressant treatment. This is referred to as paradoxical suicide , as it occurs when symptoms have already started to improve . The hypothesis is that a depressed individual may not have the energy to act on suicidal thoughts initially; however, as their condition begins to improve, their energy levels increase before their suicidal thoughts subside.
  • ➤ a person with depression might die by suicide while their symptoms show signs of improvement
  • ➤ beginning antidepressant treatment.
  • ➤ referred
  • ➤ paradoxical suicide
  • ➤ occurs when symptoms have already started to improve
  • ➤ Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 380.
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 380.

questions.text: A patient has been prescribed escitalopram for the treatment of anxiety. During a follow-up visit, the patient inquires about potential side effects of the medication. Which of the following is not a common side effect of escitalopram?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sialorrhea

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Nausea is a well-known and common side effect of escitalopram , especially when the medication is first initiated or when the dose is increased.
  • • Option A.
  • • Nausea is a well-known
  • • common side effect of escitalopram
  • • Option B. Vivid dreams or nightmares can occur with the use of escitalopram, though they are not as common as other side effects.
  • • Option B.
  • • Vivid dreams or nightmares
  • • use of escitalopram,
  • • Option C. Anorgasmia is a known sexual side effect of SSRIs , including escitalopram.
  • • Option C.
  • • Anorgasmia is a known sexual side effect of SSRIs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sialorrhea (excessive salivation) is not a common side effect of escitalopram. Sialorrhea is a common side effect of clozapine.
  • ➤ Sialorrhea
  • ➤ not a common side effect of escitalopram.
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 628-630.
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 628-630.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male has been diagnosed with recurrent depressive disorder and has had four major depressive episodes in the last five years. Each episode was characterized by feelings of worthlessness, loss of interest in daily activities, fatigue, and decreased appetite. On each occasion, the episodes resolved with treatment but he is keen to avoid further episodes in the future. His psychiatrist is discussing options for prophylactic therapy to reduce the risk of recurrence. Which of the following drugs is NOT commonly used in the prophylaxis of recurrent depressive episodes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Valproate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Lithium: Lithium is a well-established mood stabilizer that is often used for long-term prophylaxis in recurrent unipolar depressive disorder as well as in bipolar disorder.
  • • Option B. Lithium:
  • • well-established mood stabilizer
  • • used for long-term prophylaxis
  • • recurrent unipolar depressive disorder
  • • Option C. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs): SSRIs are commonly prescribed for long-term maintenance therapy to prevent recurrence of depressive episodes in patients with recurrent unipolar depression.
  • • Option C. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs):
  • • long-term maintenance therapy to prevent recurrence of depressive episodes
  • • Option D. Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs): TCAs are another class of antidepressants that can be used for long-term maintenance therapy in recurrent depressive disorder , although they are often less preferred than SSRIs due to their side effect profile.
  • • Option D. Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs):
  • • class of antidepressants that can be used for long-term maintenance therapy
  • • recurrent depressive disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the context of recurrent depressive disorder, common options for prophylactic therapy include lithium, SSRIs, and TCAs . Valproate , while a mood stabilizer and anticonvulsant, is not typically used for the prevention of recurrent unipolar depressive episodes.
  • ➤ recurrent depressive disorder, common options for prophylactic therapy include lithium, SSRIs, and TCAs
  • ➤ Valproate
  • ➤ mood stabilizer and anticonvulsant, is not typically used
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 388-391.
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 388-391.

questions.text: A 28-year-old obese female patient with schizophrenia is currently being treated with risperidone. She has recently developed galactorrhea. What should be the next step in her treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Switch to aripiprazole

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Switch to olanzapine: While olanzapine is a second-generation antipsychotic with a lower risk of hyperprolactinemia compared to risperidone , it is associated with a higher risk of weight gain and metabolic side effects . Given the patient's obesity, olanzapine may not be the best choice.
  • • Option A. Switch to olanzapine:
  • • second-generation antipsychotic with a lower risk of hyperprolactinemia compared to risperidone
  • • higher risk of weight gain and metabolic side effects
  • • Option B. Switch to haloperidol: Haloperidol is a first-generation antipsychotic that can also cause hyperprolactinemia , and it has a higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects compared to second-generation antipsychotics . Switching to haloperidol may not alleviate the patient's galactorrhea and could introduce additional side effects.
  • • Option B. Switch to haloperidol:
  • • first-generation antipsychotic that can also cause hyperprolactinemia
  • • higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects compared to second-generation antipsychotics
  • • Option C. Switch to amisulpride: Amisulpride is another second-generation antipsychotic that can cause hyperprolactinemia. Switching to amisulpride may not effectively address the patient's galactorrhea and could potentially exacerbate the issue.
  • • Option C. Switch to amisulpride:
  • • second-generation antipsychotic that can cause hyperprolactinemia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperprolactinemia can occur secondary to antipsychotic use due to blockage of D2 receptors in the tuberoinfundibular tract . Clinical features include galactorrhea, menstrual disturbances in females and gynecomastia, impotence in males. Drug of choice is aripiprazole .
  • ➤ tuberoinfundibular tract
  • ➤ Drug of choice
  • ➤ aripiprazole
  • ➤ Ref : The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 168-169.
  • ➤ Ref : The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 168-169.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the psychiatric clinic with a 2-year history of mood episodes, including periods of elevated mood, grandiose ideas, increased energy levels, and decreased need for sleep, as well as episodes of depressed mood, lack of interest, insomnia and anhedonia. She has also experienced persistent auditory hallucinations and delusion of persecution during these mood episodes, and these symptoms have been present even during periods of euthymic mood. Currently, the patient reports experiencing a depressed mood, anhedonia, and persistent auditory hallucinations. Which of the following diagnoses is most appropriate for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Bipolar I Disorder, Current Episode Depressive with Psychotic Symptoms

options.label: B
options.text: Bipolar I Disorder, Current Episode Manic with Psychotic Symptoms

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Schizoaffective Disorder

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Bipolar I Disorder, Current Episode Depressive with Psychotic Symptoms: While the patient does have episodes of depression with psychotic symptoms , this diagnosis does not account for the psychotic symptoms occurring outside of the mood episodes.
  • • Option A. Bipolar I Disorder, Current Episode Depressive with Psychotic Symptoms:
  • • patient does have episodes of depression with psychotic symptoms
  • • not account for the psychotic symptoms
  • • Option B. Bipolar I Disorder, Current Episode Manic with Psychotic Symptoms: The patient is currently experiencing a depressive episode, not a manic episode , and the presence of psychotic symptoms outside of mood episodes is not accounted for by this diagnosis.
  • • Option B. Bipolar I Disorder, Current Episode Manic with Psychotic Symptoms:
  • • experiencing a depressive episode, not a manic episode
  • • Option C. Schizophrenia: While the patient has psychotic symptoms, the presence of significant mood episodes (both manic and depressive) that are a prominent part of the clinical picture suggests a diagnosis that incorporates both mood and psychotic features, which is more consistent with Schizoaffective Disorder.
  • • Option C. Schizophrenia:
  • • patient has psychotic symptoms, the presence of significant mood episodes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by the presence of symptoms of both schizophrenia and mood disorder . Management of schizoaffective disorder include:
  • ➤ Schizoaffective disorder
  • ➤ presence of symptoms of both schizophrenia and mood disorder
  • ➤ Schizoaffective disorder (bipolar type or manic type)- Use a combination of antipsychotics and mood stabilisers Schizoaffective disorder (depressive type)- Use a combination of antipsychotics and antidepressants
  • ➤ Schizoaffective disorder (bipolar type or manic type)- Use a combination of antipsychotics and mood stabilisers
  • ➤ Schizoaffective disorder (bipolar type or manic type)- Use a combination of antipsychotics and mood stabilisers
  • ➤ Schizoaffective disorder (depressive type)- Use a combination of antipsychotics and antidepressants
  • ➤ Schizoaffective disorder (depressive type)- Use a combination of antipsychotics and antidepressants
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 342.
  • ➤ Ref : Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 342.
